intro: Nemacladus rubescens var. interior, commonly known as the interior redstem, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of North America. It is characterized by its small, clustered inflorescences and distinctive red stems that become more pronounced as the plant matures. The species belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible parts. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
